awd_titl_txt: CAREER: An Interdisciplinary Study of Learning: Student Understanding of Linear Algebra in Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Title:
CAREER: An Interdisciplinary Study Of Learning: Student Understanding Of Linear Algebra In Physics


Consistent with the national charge for the advancement of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines, the National Research Council's (NRC's) report (2012) "Discipline-Based Education Research: Understanding and Improving Learning in Undergraduate Science and Engineering" describes a need for interdisciplinary studies regarding learning and the transfer of knowledge for students in upper division STEM courses.   This project will contribute towards this national need for basic research by investigating students' learning and understanding of key topics and ideas from linear algebra - a fundamental mathematics topic for STEM majors in multiple disciplines - as applied to undergraduate upper-division physics. In connection with this, the project will provide new insights in improving undergraduate education within the STEM disciplines. The results of this study will not only extend the research base of what is known about student understanding of mathematics and physics across disciplines, but it will also contribute to pedagogical implications at the undergraduate level by leveraging the synergy between mathematics and physics education research on teaching and learning. The project will also contribute to the development of innovative assessment instruments for undergraduate mathematics learning.
  
The project will integrate research and education to investigate eigentheory and related key ideas from linear algebra within the framework of quantum physics. The research focal points will be to: (1) characterize the various ways in which students reason about and symbolize concepts related to eigentheory in quantum physics; (2) determine how students' language and symbols for concepts related to eigentheory compare and contrast across mathematics contexts and quantum physics contexts; and (3) explore how instructors' use of language and mathematical symbols relates to students' understanding, symbolization, and interpretation of eigentheory in quantum physics. To help foster and diversify the research investigations, data will be collected from the quantum physics courses at three academic institutions: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University; Oregon State University; and the University of Maine. The project will also produce and vet a conceptually oriented multiple-choice extension (MCE) assessment instrument for eigentheory. Included in the research to address items (1)-(3) listed above will be textbook analysis, the MCE eigentheory instrument creation and implementation, interview protocol development and implementation, classroom observations and interviews with participating instructors, and bridging sequences development. To enhance and expand the overall infrastructure and collaborations for research and education across disciplines, this instrument together with research results from the investigations will be disseminated widely through research and practitioner publications, presentations, and workshops in mathematics and physics education.

por.por_cntn:
The driving research aims for this project were to contribute to what is known about how university students understand, symbolize, and interpret concepts related to eigentheory in quantum mechanics, and how students? language and symbols for concepts related to eigentheory compare and contrast across mathematics and quantum mechanics. The project focused on eigentheory because it is a conceptually complex idea that builds from and relies upon student understanding of multiple key ideas in mathematics, and its application is widespread in mathematics and beyond. In quantum mechanics, for instance, eigenvalues of various Hermitian operators represent possible measured values of corresponding observables.

To pursue the project research aims, the research team collected data from Quantum Mechanics classrooms at two participating institutions and linear algebra students at a third university. The data produced a variety of results related to how student made sense of linear algebra concepts (without any physics context) and quantum mechanics problems (that involved linear algebra concepts), as well as how they made notational choices and reasoned about the interplay between mathematics and physics. Collectively, this work has scholarly significance because it sheds light on student understanding of important transdisciplinary topics and can in turn inform pedagogy.

For example, in Serbin and Wawro (2022), we asked students to consider a specific state and calculate the probabilities that its spin component is up or down along the z-axis and up or down along the y-axis (which involves a change in basis, a linear algebra concept). Results show that students use intricate, nonuniform problem-solving methods with reasoning that moves fluidly between structural (mathematizing and interpreting) and technical (conceptual and procedural) skills in quick succession; and student reasoning about orthonormal bases, change of basis, inner products, and probability informed their flexibility in choosing problem-solving approaches. This analysis illuminates that students? quantum mechanical problem solving does not follow a simple modeling cycle, gives evidences of the complexity of skills involved in the problem solving, and exemplifies the inextricability of mathematics and physics in students? reasoning at this level. With respect to teaching implications, our research contributes to raising the mathematics community?s awareness of what concepts from mathematics courses are used and in what way by students in physics courses. Linear algebra instructors could integrate problems into their course that not only facilitate the development of conceptual and procedural skills from linear algebra but also demonstrate the mathematization of linear algebra in quantum mechanics. In another study (Wawro et al., 2020), we investigated how students' meanings for eigentheory compare and contrast across mathematics and quantum physics contexts. We analyzed students' interpretations of the same mathematical eigenequation and a quantum mechanical spin eigenequation. Results characterize students' nuanced imagery for the equations and highlight instances of synergistic and incompatible interpretations. For instance, a frequently helpful conceptualization in mathematics, that eigenvectors are those that are stretched by the matrix, is not appropriate in the quantum mechanical setting. The quantum spin eigenequation seems conceptually distinct not only from eigenequations in mathematics but also from other physics equations, which can often be conceptualized as direct mappings of relationships between physical quantities. 

With respect to the intellectual merit, the project created a cohesive and transformative study across both research and practice. The results not only extended the research base and produce new knowledge about student understanding of mathematics and physics, but it also contributed pedagogical implications at the undergraduate level. The broader impact of the study speaks to the current national need for the advancement of STEM disciplines. The results directly benefit society by helping to improve undergraduate education within the STEM disciplines. New results about students? interdisciplinary understanding of mathematics and physics helps generate insight into student cognition that is relevant to subject matter, courses, and disciplines beyond those investigated in only this research project. The project also leveraged the synergy between mathematics and physics education research into effective pedagogical approaches at the undergraduate level. Furthermore, the project enhanced the infrastructure for research and education by establishing collaborations between Virginia Tech and other prominent U.S. academic institutions. Results were published in both research and practitioner journals within mathematics, mathematics education, and physics education research journals. Outcomes were shared through presentations at mathematics, mathematics education, and other STEM education conferences, both nationally and internationally. Finally, this project built capacity in the field related to graduate education and mentorship by providing funds for two graduate research assistants and seven students. In addition, 5 peer-reviewed journal articles and 10 conference proceeding papers had a student co-author, and numerous student conference presentations were funded. One dissertation grew out of the student?s involvement in this project.
